headline.main: The Abortion Issue: Who Decides? (5 Letters)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Abortion Foes See Validation for New Tactic'' (front page, May 22):
docs.abstract: Five letters comment on impact of Supreme Court decision upholding law banning certain late-term abortions (May 22 article); Judge Elizabeth Doyle calls decision insulting to women and dangerous erosion of their rights; Jessica Sporn describes positive impact on her life of her decision to have abortion; Dr Nada L Stotland, president-elect of American Psychiatric Assn, cites research refuting claim of causal relationship between abortions and mental illness; Candace De Puy argues complex emotions are part of everyday life; Prof Dena S Davis finds decision outrageous; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Abortion Foes See Validation for New Tactic'' (front page, May 22):

docs.lead_paragraph: The director of “The 40-Year-Old Virgin” and now “Knocked Up” makes comedies about saving yourself for marriage and staying together for the sake of the kids. What’s so funny about that?

headline.seo: Judd Apatow - Motion Pictures - Knocked Up - 40-Year-Old Virgin

docs.lead_paragraph: Three women earned a place on the starting grid of 33 drivers for Sunday’s Indy 500, a first for a race that cut its teeth in 1911.

headline.main: Creeping Equality, a Bit of Fraternity and a Slick of Asterisks at Indy
headline.print_headline: Creeping Equality, A Bit of Fraternity And a Slick Of Asterisks at Indy

docs.snippet: Three women earned a place on the starting grid of 33 drivers for Sunday’s Indy 500, a first for a race that cut its teeth in 1911.

docs.lead_paragraph: Racing a Missile in the Gaza Strip Palestinians, left, ran as a missile fired by the Israeli Army came down on a Hamas post in the central Gaza Strip. A Palestinian boy, right, reacted to the blast. The Israelis hit at least eight different locations. PAGE A4 Cleric Reappears in Iraq With New Call for Unity Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric who had spent the last few months in Iran, resurfaced in Iraq, delivering a fiery anti-American speech in the city of Kufa and calling for national unity among Shiites, Sunnis and Iraqi Christians. He also demanded a withdrawal of American troops. PAGE A6 Joust Over Prewar Warnings Democrats on a deeply divided Senate Intelligence Committee accused the Bush administration of ignoring preinvasion warnings from the nation's spy agencies that a war in Iraq could foster violence and division, and that it could strengthen Al Qaeda and Iran. PAGE A8 U.S. Rejects Emission Plan The United States has rejected Germany's proposal for deep long-term cuts in greenhouse gas emissions, setting the stage for a battle that will pit President Bush against his European allies at a coming meeting of the world's richest countries. PAGE A3 Flight of the Condo Investors As dozens of condominium towers conceived during Florida's real estate boom near completion, investors who had snatched up units in the preconstruction phase are increasingly trying to break contracts. PAGE A9 THIS WEEKEND What's So Funny About. . . Out-of-wedlock pregnancy? Judd Apatow, who makes Hollywood comedies like the new ''Knocked Up,'' wants to show you. MAGAZINE Graham Greene's Capri The rich's summer playground is also where Greene found solitude to write many of his 26 novels. TRAVEL

docs.lead_paragraph: TRENTON, May 24 — Employees of many New Jersey businesses would be entitled to up to 10 weeks of family leave with partial pay for a new baby, a difficult pregnancy or an ill parent or spouse, under a measure approved on Thursday by a Senate committee.

headline.main: Lawmakers in New Jersey Advance Bill on Paid Leave

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Atul Gawande's May 19 column about abortion doesn't mention a significant contributor to abortion: alcohol and drug abuse. Individuals, whether young teenagers or those in the 18-to-25 age group, in which abortions are concentrated, who are high on alcohol or other drugs like marijuana are likelier to have risky sex.
docs.abstract: Letter from Joseph A Califano Jr, chairman of National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse, contends drug and alcohol abuse contribute to abortion because parties are more likely to engage in risky sex (May 19 Atul Gawande Op-Ed article)
